comment.body: I didn't get what these directives are for. Could you add documentation on that somewhere close to the C# runtime or compiler?

pull_request.title: feat: Populate runtimes with all built-in declarations
pull_request.body:
### Description
Fixes #511

Generalizes the approach used in #2284 to pre-generate all built-in declarations into the various runtimes:

* Adds an internal `--system-module` option to control how the system module is treated when translating:
  * Include (the current default) - emits code for the contents of the System module
  * Omit (the new default) - emits no code for the System module
  * Populate - emits ONLY the code for the System module
* The third option is used to generate part of each runtime from a `systemModulePopulator.dfy` file, previously named `tuplesForDafnyRuntime.dfy`. The output is now present in each runtime in a separate file/source location, and checked for consistency in CI just as other Dafny-generated committed source is.
* Also generalized how the runtime files are embedded in `DafnyPipeline` to support more than one file better (as Go already was).

TODOs:

* [x] Mechanism to check arities against the limit of 20 when --system-module is Omit
* [x] Remove `internal` from C# helper code (and tests to confirm it works)
* [x] Feature for pre-compiling built-ins (opt out for C++ and Rust for now)
* [ ] Reference manual section on this topic (for feature to point to)

### How has this been tested?
Mostly existing tests, but also added an internal version of `--include-runtime` for `dafny run`, so that `%testDafnyForEachCompiler` can include testing on C# when using the separate `DafnyRuntime.dll` library, as that behaves significantly different in this case.

<small>By submitting this pull request, I confirm that my contribution is made under the terms of the [MIT license](https://github.com/dafny-lang/dafny/blob/master/LICENSE.txt).</small>

pull_request.title: Fix spurious warning about vacuous proof
pull_request.body:
There were two utility methods to translate the predicate associated with an assert statement. Both could translate it into an assumption in Boogie under certain circumstances. One avoided recording it as a proof obligation in this case, but the other didn’t. Now it does.

### How has this been tested?

The new test case, `git-issues/PR4715Test.dfy`, generates no warnings. (It did generate a warning prior to this PR.)

By submitting this pull request, I confirm that my contribution is made under the terms of the MIT license.

issue.title: Removed fuel from encoding of Dafny opaque functions
issue.body:
At present, for encoding opaque functions, Dafny sets it with 0 fuel, and inserts a boolean flag which guards whether the body of the opaque function is available or not. These two mechanisms essentially perform the same function and thus are redundant.

This PR is an attempt to make the dafny encoding of opaque functions leaner by getting rid of the fuel in Dafn'y encoding of opaque functions. 

<!-- Is this a user-visible change?  Remember to update RELEASE_NOTES.md -->

<!-- Is this a bug fix?  Remember to include a test in Test/git-issues/ -->

<!-- Is this a bug fix for an issue introduced in the latest release?  Mention this in the PR details and ensure a patch release is considered -->

<!-- Does this PR need tests?  Add them to `Test/` or to `Source/*.Test/…` and run them with `dotnet test` -->

<!-- Are you moving a large amount of code? Read CONTRIBUTING.md to learn how to do that while maintaining git history -->

<small>By submitting this pull request, I confirm that my contribution is made under the terms of the [MIT license](https://github.com/dafny-lang/dafny/blob/master/LICENSE.txt).</small>

comment.body: (Responding a bit late.) If a default can be determined already in the parser, that may be a good place. At the other extreme, if the default matters only for verification (which I think is the case here), then we could choose never to update the AST with the default, and instead just take the appropriate action in the verifier. Here, it's now done in "Pass 1", which is alright. The one place we should avoid placing it, I think, is in the name resolution + type inference ("Pass 0"), because that pass is quite delicate.

pull_request.title: Method reads fix
pull_request.body:
### Description

* Move initial processing of method `reads` clauses from `Method.Resolve` (which is called during name resolution + type inference) to later in the Resolver pipeline. This not only helps declutter the name resolution phase, but it also makes `reads` processing apply to both (legacy and refresh) resolvers.
* Fix various scoping issues of attribute resolution (e.g., include function result name in the scope).
* Remove some old code in new resolver for things that are now being checked later in the resolution pipeline.
* Make `{:warnShadowing}` be the same as `{:warnShadowing true}` (not `{:warnShadowing false}`)

Minor changes:

* fix: (new resolver) Resolve attributes of `:| assume`.
* fix: Reuse `.MethodCallInfo` if called to compute it again
* fix: Include method `reads` clauses in pretty print

### How has this been tested?

The `dafny0/AttributeChecks.dfy` and `dafny0/Shadows.dfy` tests have been updated.

<small>By submitting this pull request, I confirm that my contribution is made under the terms of the [MIT license](https://github.com/dafny-lang/dafny/blob/master/LICENSE.txt).</small>

issue.title: Add placeholder modules

comment.body:
> The problem I have with this approach is that it's no longer possible to replace the standard library shipped with a version of Dafny with another standard library (i.e. an updated version)

I'm not too concerned with that since for now the standard libraries are tightly coupled to the Dafny distribution, and in some cases we'll take advantage of that to provide libraries like `Interop` that may need to change with each Dafny version.

> This is a strong hint for me that a better way to ship the standard library for Dafny is to ship the files, stored in plain in Dafny.exe and regurgitated on demand, and not include them or precompile them in the Dafny Runtime.

I do think it would be unfortunate to provide standard libraries but force users that need a single compiled version of them to build and distribute it themselves. We could consider distributing the compiled standard libraries as a separate package in each language instead of adding them to the runtimes, but that seems like more overhead for both us and customers without a lot of benefit right now.

issue.title: Add placeholder modules
Add placeholder modules

issue.title: Add placeholder modules

comment.body:
> Correct me if I'm wrong @robin-aws , but when we will include the standard library in Dafny itself, we will include files, based on what the user imports, not based on the compiler's mode. So ideally, our standard library has late bindings for all supported languages and the compiler will just pick the one that is the most relevant to the compilation mode, or say something like "language blah does not have a replacing module for X defined in Y. Please define one yourself."

My plan is that the `DafnyStandardLibraries.doo` file that `--standard-libraries` implicitly adds for verification will just have the abstract/replacable `FileIO` module in it, let's say in a `FileIO.dfy` file. There will be other Dafny files defining the concrete module implementation for each target, `FileIOForJava.dfy` for example. And for completeness let's say there's a supporting Java file like `FileIO.java`. All three files will be compiled into the Java runtime: the Java files output from compiling `FileIO.dfy` and `FileIOForJava.dfy`, and `FileIO.java`. That means there will be a Makefile command something like this to run before building `DafnyRuntime.jar`:

```make
dafny translate java FileIO.dfy FileIOForJava.dfy ... --output DafnyStandardLibraries
cp -r DafnyStandardLibraries-java DafnyRuntimeJava/src/main/dafny-generated
```

I didn't set this up in the initial PR to add stdlib support because #511 means you hit duplicate definitions when you try to add Dafny-generated code to the runtimes, much worse than existing contexts, so I'm fixing that first. https://github.com/dafny-lang/dafny/pull/4658 already adds some similar make targets to pre-compile the `_System` module into the runtimes, though.

Having project file features for collecting the right input files into `dafny translate` would certainly be nice, but in the actual Makefile it's not too hard to collect them with globs. 

I think you're right that this can work without `replaceable` modules, by having consumers refer to an undefined `FileIO` module that is filed in at compile time by one of the target-specific versions. I can say from doing [something similar for the `UnicodeStrings` module](https://github.com/dafny-lang/libraries/blob/master/src/Unicode/UnicodeStrings.dfy) that it's a real pain when writing the code, because you have unresolved references the IDE can't deal with, so you're stuck with verifying using the CLI.

review.body: Nice work! I look forward to using "replaceable" modules for better foreign-language interop.
